author: m.kalinin
content:
Will the procedure looks like as follows?
1) there is a 51% attack
2) there is a corresponding reaction with `(X, T)` announcement
3) everyone restarts their beacon nodes with `T` (to initiate transition) and execution engines with `X` (to sort out malicious forks)
4) merge is happening at `T` picking up the head of the chain (from the chain segment of descendants of `X`)

What would stop attackers from doing double spend on the fork `X`? `T` should give a time that would be enough for the merge coordination, which would also give attacker enough time to react.

author: dkdkdkdkdkdk
content: you mean they would start a new fork after `X`?

author: m.kalinin
content: right, if they have enough blocks prior the merge for a double spend they could do it there. To prevent this possibility we could socially communicate exact block hash `X` that would be the last PoW block and PoS-secured chain would be built on top of this block. It would cause downtime but downtime period sounds better than successful double spend.
